exercise: First Law of Motion
The speed of an object in a given direction.
Second Law of Motion
The paired forces that occur when one object exerts a force on another object and vice versa.
Third Law of Motion
The rate at which an object changes its velocity, affected by the net force and mass.
Inertia
The overall force acting on an object when all individual forces are combined.
Acceleration
An interaction that, when unopposed, will change the motion of an object, measured in newtons (N).
Force
The force that opposes the motion of an object, often causing it to slow down.
Mass
A branch of physics that deals with the motion of bodies under the action of forces.
Velocity
A measure of the amount of matter in an object, typically measured in kilograms (kg).
Net Force
The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.
Friction
The tendency of objects to resist changes in their state of motion.
Action-Reaction
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
Classical Mechanics
An object at rest will remain at rest, and an object in motion will remain in motion unless acted upon by an unbalanced external force.

solution.First Law of Motion: An object at rest will remain at rest, and an object in motion will remain in motion unless acted upon by an unbalanced external force.
solution.Second Law of Motion: The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.
solution.Third Law of Motion: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
solution.Inertia: The tendency of objects to resist changes in their state of motion.
solution.Acceleration: The rate at which an object changes its velocity, affected by the net force and mass.
solution.Force: An interaction that, when unopposed, will change the motion of an object, measured in newtons (N).
solution.Mass: A measure of the amount of matter in an object, typically measured in kilograms (kg).
solution.Velocity: The speed of an object in a given direction.
solution.Net Force: The overall force acting on an object when all individual forces are combined.
solution.Friction: The force that opposes the motion of an object, often causing it to slow down.
solution.Action-Reaction: The paired forces that occur when one object exerts a force on another object and vice versa.
solution.Classical Mechanics: A branch of physics that deals with the motion of bodies under the action of forces.
